topics: The Core Conflict of Classic and Value Project Management
The Impact of Project Risks and Project Uncertainties
Relations between Project Variation and Project Value
Client Perspective: Stakeholder Analysis and Evaluation
Resource Perspective: Critical Chain Single Project Level
Resource Perspective: Critical Chain Multi Project Level
Resource Perspective: Critical Chain Risk Management

grading.policies: The instructor reserves discretion to grade down for poor writing, poor team participation, and delayed submission.

policies.attendance: Class attendance is recorded for every lecture. Absences beyond the first 2 will result in 10 points per subsequent absence deducted from the participation grade. Students who miss more than four classes have to retake the course.
policies.late_work: Assignments received 1-6 days late will have 20% of the total points deducted; assignments received more than one week late will receive 0 points.
policies.academic_integrity: All assignments may be submitted to www.turnitin.com for originality evaluation. Students must adhere to the Graduate Student Code of Academic Integrity.
policies.accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology provides accommodations for students with documented disabilities through the Office of Disability Services.

additional_info.course_format: This course is an online-class course. All materials and many actions are online.
additional_info.technology_requirements: Basic computer and web-browsing skills, live web conferencing using Zoom, recording and uploading video via Panopto.
additional_info.support_resources: For more information about course access or support, contact the Technology Resource and Assistance Center (TRAC) by calling 201-216-5500.

_metadata.course_description: This course will introduce students to the Stevens’ concept of Project Value Management.
learning_outcomes: Understand and apply innovative frameworks, concepts and tools to strategically managing projects in organizations.
Assess the value of Project Value Management by understanding the limitations of classic approaches to project management.
Use the project value paradigm to manage projects strategically at the levels of planning, execution, and control towards achieving value.
Develop a project strategy to maximize the project’s value for key shareholders and stakeholders.
Select the appropriate set of tools to manage projects strategically.
Understand and differentiate between project risks and project uncertainties.
